elements.content: Six novel complexes, [Zn(IIMB)4(H2O)2](NO3)2·5H2O 1, {[Ag2(IIMB)2][2,6-C10H6(COO)2]·6H2O} n 2, {[Cu(IIMB)2]Br2·0.5H2O} n 3, {[Co(IIMB)2(SCN)2]} n 4, {[Cu(IIMB)2(SO4)]·8.5H2O} n 5, and {[Co(IIMB)2(H2O)(SO4)]4·29H2O} n 6, were obtained by reactions of 1-(1-imidazolyl)-4-(imidazol-1-ylmethyl)benzene (IIMB) with the corresponding metal salts. X-ray diffraction analyses reveal that 1 is monomeric, in which IIMB acts as monodentate ligand, while the IIMB ligand in complexes 2 − 6 acts as bidentate ligand. Complex 2 has a single chain structure, while complexes 3 and 4 are double stranded chains. Complexes 5 and 6 display similar 2-D polycatenated architectures formed by the inclined interpenetration of 1-D double stranded chains. This kind of 1-D → 2-D inclined interpenetration has rarely been reported until now. In addition, the photoluminescence properties of the synthesized compounds were investigated in the solid state at room temperature.

X-ray diffraction analyses reveal that 1 is monomeric, in which IIMB acts as monodentate ligand, while the IIMB ligand in complexes 2 - 6 acts as bidentate ligand. Complex 2 has a single chain structure, while complexes 3 and 4 are double stranded chains. Complexes 5 and 6 display similar 2-D polycatenated architectures formed by the inclined interpenetration of 1-D double stranded chains. This kind of 1-D → 2-D inclined interpenetration has rarely been reported until now. In addition, the photoluminescence properties of the synthesized compounds were investigated in the solid state at room temperature.

elements.content: Recently, coordination polymeric frameworks have attracted great attention due to their potential applications in the areas of magnetism, nonlinear optics, electronics, catalysis, and molecular recognition and sorption and their intriguing structure topologies, such as honeycomb, brick wall, grid, ladder, herringbone, diamondoid, polycatenanes, and polyrotaxanes. The coordination polymers can be specially designed by careful selection of the metal ions with definite coordination geometry, the structure of the connecting ligands, the nature of counteranions, and the reaction conditions. Although it is not yet possible to prepare fully predictable frameworks on the basis of rational design, the selection of the structure of the spacer ligands is extremely important because changing the structure of the organic ligand can control and adjust the topology of coordination frameworks. For example, the ligand 1,3,5-tris(imidazol-1-ylmethyl)-2,4,6-trimethylbenzene gave an infinite 1-D tubelike structure by reaction with zinc(II) acetate, and the ligand 1,3,5-tris(imidazol-1-ylmethyl)benzene gave a M3L2 cage-like complex by reaction with zinc(II) acetate. Thus, there is still a long way to go to rationalize the design of compounds with well-defined structures and useful functions by developing new architectures of coordination polymers using spacer ligands.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Recently, coordination polymeric frameworks have attracted great attention due to their potential applications in the areas of magnetism, nonlinear optics, electronics, catalysis, and molecular recognition and sorption and their intriguing structure topologies, such as honeycomb, brick wall, grid, ladder, herringbone, diamondoid, polycatenanes, and polyrotaxanes. The coordination polymers can be specially designed by careful selection of the metal ions with definite coordination geometry, the structure of the connecting ligands, the nature of counteranions, and the reaction conditions. Although it is not yet possible to prepare fully predictable frameworks on the basis of rational design, the selection of the structure of the spacer ligands is extremely important because changing the structure of the organic ligand can control and adjust the topology of coordination frameworks. For example, the ligand 1,3,5-tris(imidazol-1-ylmethyl)-2,4,6-trimethylbenzene gave an infinite 1-D tubelike structure by reaction with zinc(II) acetate, and the ligand 1,3,5-tris(imidazol-1-ylmethyl)benzene gave a M3L2 cage-like complex by reaction with zinc(II) acetate. Thus, there is still a long way to go to rationalize the design of compounds with well-defined structures and useful functions by developing new architectures of coordination polymers using spacer ligands.

elements.content: In the previous studies, it has been reported that the flexible bridging ligand 1,4-bis(imidazole-1-ylmethyl)benzene (bix) gave a 3-D framework by reaction with cobalt(II) acetate and sodium nitrite or cobalt sulfate, an infinite 2-D polyrotaxane network by reactions with silver(I) nitrate or zinc(II) nitrate hexahydrate, and an infinite 1-D chain with manganese(II) nitrite. The ligand 4,4‘-bis(imidazole-1-ylmethyl)biphenyl gave an infinite 1-D chain containing polymetallocages by reaction with manganese(II) perchlorate and an infinite double stranded helix with zinc(II) acetate and two 2-D grid networks with cadmium(II) chloride. The ligand N,N‘-butylenebisimidazole formed an interpenetrating 3-D network by reaction with manganese(II) nitrite. To further investigate the influence of the bridging ligand on the formation of supramolecular complexes, we designed and prepared a imidazole-containing ligand, 1-(1-imidazolyl)-4-(imidazol-1-ylmethyl)benzene (IIMB), and used the ligand to generate some coordination polymers with interesting topologies. Here, we report the crystal structure and photoluminescence properties of six novel complexes [Zn(IIMB)4(H2O)2](NO3)2·5H2O 1, {[Ag2(IIMB)2][2,6-C10H6(COO)2]·6H2O} n 2, {[Cu(IIMB)2]Br2·0.5H2O} n 3, {[Co(IIMB)2(SCN)2]} n 4, {[Cu(IIMB)2(SO4)]·8.5H2O} n 5, and {[Co(IIMB)2(H2O)(SO4)]4·29H2O} n 6.

elements.content: All commercially available chemicals are of reagent grade and used as received without further purification. Elemental analyses for C, H, and N were carried out on a Perkin-Elmer 240C elemental analyzer at the Analysis Center of Nanjing University. The luminescent spectra for the solid samples were recorded at room temperature on an Aminco Bowman Series 2 spectrofluorometer with a xenon arc lamp as the light source. The ligand 1-(1-imidazolyl)-4-(imidazol-1-ylmethyl)benzene (IIMB) was synthesized by Ullmann condensation method between imidazole and 1-bromo-4-(imidazol-1-ylmethyl)benzene, which was prepared by reaction of 4-bromobenzyl bromide with imidazole under alkaline conditions. The procedures for synthesis and measurements of the silver(I) complexes were carried out in dark.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Procedures

All commercially available chemicals are of reagent grade and used as received without further purification. Elemental analyses for C, H, and N were carried out on a Perkin-Elmer 240C elemental analyzer at the Analysis Center of Nanjing University. The luminescent spectra for the solid samples were recorded at room temperature on an Aminco Bowman Series 2 spectrofluorometer with a xenon arc lamp as the light source. The ligand 1-(1-imidazolyl)-4-(imidazol-1-ylmethyl)benzene (IIMB) was synthesized by Ullmann condensation method between imidazole and 1-bromo-4-(imidazol-1-ylmethyl)benzene, which was prepared by reaction of 4-bromobenzyl bromide with imidazole under alkaline conditions. The procedures for synthesis and measurements of the silver(I) complexes were carried out in dark.

elements.content: Synthesis of [Zn(IIMB) 4 (H 2 O) 2 ](NO 3 ) 2 ·5H 2 O (1). A solution of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (29.7 mg, 0.1 mmol) in water (20 mL) was added to a solution of IIMB (89.6 mg, 0.4 mmol) in H2O(10 mL). The mixture was stirred for ca. 30 min and then filtrated. Complex 1 was obtained by slow evaporation of the filtrate at room temperature in 48% yield. Anal. Calcd. for C52H62N18O13Zn:  C 51.51, H 5.15, N 20.79; found:  C 51.48, H 5.07, N 20.74.

elements.content: Synthesis of {[Ag 2 (IIMB) 2 ][2,6-C 10 H 6 (COO) 2 ]·6H 2 O} n (2). A solution of IIMB (44.8 mg, 0.2 mmol) in methanol (7 mL) was layered over an aqueous solution of freshly prepared [Ag(NH3)2]2[2,6-C10H6(COO)2] (2,6-C10H6(COO)2 = 2,6-naphthalenedicarboxylate, 0.05 mmol mL-1, 4 mL). Colorless single crystals of 2 suitable for X-ray diffraction analysis were obtained by slow interlayer diffusion in 58% yield. Anal. Calcd. For C38H42Ag2N8O10:  C 46.27, H 4.29, N 11.36; found:  C 46.29, H 4.24, N 11.41.

elements.content: Synthesis of {[Cu(IIMB) 2 (SO 4 )]·8.5H 2 O} n (5). A solution of IIMB (67.2 mg, 0.3 mmol) in methanol (5 mL) and CuSO4·5H2O (37.5 mg, 0.15 mmol) in water (10 mL) was sealed in a stainless steel vessel and placed in an oven at 85 °C for 3 days. The bomb was cooled to room temperature, and then the solution was filtered. The complex 5 was obtained by slow evaporation of the filtrate at room temperature in 42% yield. Anal. Calcd. for C26H41CuN8O12.50S:  C 41.02, H 5.43, N 14.72; found:  C 41.21, H 5.38, N 14.80.

elements.content: Crystallography. The X-ray diffraction measurements for complexes 1 − 6 were carried out on a Rigaku RAXIS−RAPID imaging plate diffractometer at 200 K, using graphite-monochromated MoKα radiation (λ = 0.7107 Å). The structures were solved by direct methods using SIR92 and expanded using Fourier techniques. The C201, C202, C203, C204, C205, C206, C207, C208, C209, and C210 atoms in complex 2 are disordered into two positions with a site occupation factor of 0.517(7) and 0.483(7), respectively. In addition, the O121 in 6 is disordered into two positions with a site occupation factor of 0.730(13) and 0.270(13), respectively. In complex 6, lattice water molecules are disordered, for example, the O123 is disordered into two positions with site occupation factors of 0.621(11) and 0.379(11), respectively; the O125 is disordered into two positions with site occupation factors of 0.674(16) and 0.326(16), respectively; the O129 is disordered into two positions with site occupation factors of 0.208(17) and 0.792(17), respectively; the O131 is disordered into two positions with site occupation factors of 0.751(12) and 0.249(12), respectively; the O133 is disordered into two positions with site occupation factors of 0.376(6) and 0.647(15), respectively; and the O135 and O137 are disordered into two positions with site occupation factors of 0.353(15) and 0.647(15), respectively. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically by the full-matrix least-squares method. Hydrogen atoms were generated geometrically expect for those of water molecules. The crystal parameters, data collection, and refinement results for complexes 1−6 are summarized in Table . Further details are provided in the Supporting Information.

Crystal Structure Description. Complex [Zn(IIMB) 4 (H 2 O) 2 ](NO 3 ) 2 ·5H 2 O, (1). When the reaction of ligand IIMB with zinc(II) nitrate was carried out in aqueous solution, compound 1 was obtained. The result of crystallographic analysis showed that 1 is a mononuclear compound. A similar mononuclear compound was obtained by the reaction of IIMB with cadmium nitrate or manganese chloride. However, when the reaction was carried out in the mixture of water and methanol, the compound with 1-D tubular chain structure was isolated. Figure a shows a view of the coordination environment of metal atom in 1 with the atom numbering scheme. The coordination geometry around the zinc(II) atom is distorted octahedral with N4O2 binding set. Each zinc atom is coordinated by four imidazole nitrogen atoms from four individual IIMB ligands with the average bond length of Zn−Nav 2.15 Å and two water molecules in a trans arrangement with Zn−O bond lengths of 2.154(7) and 2.144(6) Å (Table S1). It is clear that only the imidazole group connected to the benzene ring through methylene group coordinates to the Zn(II) atom, and the one connected to benzene ring directly remains free of coordination. Two nitrogen atoms (N312, N212) of uncoordinated imidazole groups form intermolecular O−H···N hydrogen bonds [the O···N distances are 2.791(10) and 2.729(9) Å (Table S2)] with the oxygen atoms of coordinated water molecules to generate an infinite 2-D network structure of 1 (Figure b) with the other two ligands lie above or below the network pointing to the opposite directions (Figure S1). These networks packed together to form a 3-D structure, which was stabilized by weak π−π interactions of two nearby benzene ring planes with the center-to-center distances of 3.96, 4.00, and 4.01 Å. The nitrate anions and lattice water molecules are located in the voids formed between two adjacent cationic layers, held there by eight CH···O hydrogen bonds, the distances of C···O ranging from 2.659(16) to 3.395(11) Å (Table S2). The distances from 2.67(1) to 3.07(1) Å between the O atoms of water molecules or between the O atoms of water molecule and the O atom of nitrate anion indicate the formation of OH···O hydrogen bonds (Table S2), although the hydrogen atoms of water molecules could not be found.

The nitrate anions and lattice water molecules are located in the voids formed between two adjacent cationic layers, held there by eight CH⋅⋅⋅O hydrogen bonds, the distances of C⋅⋅⋅O ranging from 2.659(16) to 3.395(11) Å (Table S2). The distances from 2.67(1) to 3.07(1) Å between the O atoms of water molecules or between the O atoms of water molecule and the O atom of nitrate anion indicate the formation of OH⋅⋅⋅O hydrogen bonds (Table S2), although the hydrogen atoms of water molecules could not be found.

elements.content: Complexes {[Ag 2 (IIMB) 2 ][2,6-C 10 H 6 (COO) 2 ]·6H 2 O} n (2), {[Cu(IIMB) 2 ]Br 2 ·0.5H 2 O} n (3), and {[Co(IIMB) 2 (SCN) 2 ]} n (4). The X-ray crystallographic analysis revealed that the structure of 2 is a 1-D zigzag chain and that there are two silver(I) atoms in an asymmetric unit. Each silver(I) atom is coordinated by two N atoms of two different ligands with nearly linear coordination geometry [N42−Ag1−N12 = 173.50(16)° and N112−Ag2−N142 = 177.48(18)° and Ag−N bond lengths in the range of 2.098(4)∼2.118(4) Å (Table S1)] (Figure a); in turn, each ligand connects two Ag1 atoms (or two Ag2 atoms) to give a zigzag chain structure. These 1-D chains arrange in the bc plane to form a layer by face-to-face π−π interaction between imidazole ring plane and benzene ring plane with the centroid−centroid separation 3.92 Å (Figure b). The 2,6-naphthalenedicarboxylic anions and lattice water molecules sandwich between two cationic layers and are held there by C−H···O hydrogen bonds (Table S2, Figure S2).

elements.content: Compound 3 was readily prepared by the reaction of IIMB ligand with copper(II) bromide. The structure of compound 3 was determined by X-ray crystallography. As illustrated in Figure a, the copper atom has a slightly distorted square planar environment and is coordinated by four nitrogen atoms of four IIMB ligands with the copper(II) atom lies in the N4 plane, and the Cu−N bond lengths are 2.004(3) and 2.023(3) Å, (Table S1). Complex 3 is a wavelike 1-D double stranded chain containing 24-membered rings with a Cu···Cu intrachain distance of 11.17 Å (Figure b). In the ring, the benzene ring planes are nearly parallel to the chain plane since the dihedral angles between the benzene ring plane and the chain plane defined by copper atoms and methylene carbon atoms are both 10.4°. Weak overlap occurs between the benzene ring planes from two adjacent chains since the center-to-center distance between the two nearest benzene ring planes is 4.08 Å (Figure S3).

elements.content: When the IIMB ligand reacted with cobalt(II) thiocyanate, the compound 4 was successfully isolated. X-ray crystallographic analysis revealed that the structure of 4 is a 1-D wavelike chain like that of 3 except that the thiocyanate anion participated in coordination. There are two cobalt(II) atoms in one asymmetric unit of 4. Figure a exhibits the crystal structure of 4 together with the atom numbering scheme. Cobalt atoms are at a slightly distorted octahedral coordination environment. The equatorial positions are occupied by four nitrogen atoms of imidazole groups from four different IIMB ligands (the Co−N bond lengths range from 2.109(3) to 2.169(3) Å, Table S1), and two N atoms from two thiocyanate anions occupy the axial positions with bond lengths of 2.154(3) and 2.110(3) Å. The Co−N bond lengths are similar to those of the reported coordination polymers [Co(bbbt)2(NCS)2] n (where bbbt is 1,1‘-(1,4)-butanediyl)bis-1H-benzotriazole, Co−Nbbbt(av) = 2.218 Å and Co−NNCS = 2.055(4) Å) and [Co(NCS)2(bpms)2] n (where bpms is 1,2-bis(4-pyridylmethyl)disulfenyl, Co−Nbpms(av) = 2.218 Å and Co−NNCS = 2.085 Å). Each IIMB ligand in turn links two cobalt(II) atoms to generate a 1-D wavelike chain. These chains range along ab plane to form a 2-D network sheet, and the structure was stabilized by a CH···S hydrogen bond and weak π−π interactions between two adjacent chains since the nearest center-to-center distance of the benzene ring planes is 4.07 Å (Table S2, Figure b).

elements.content: As mentioned previously, the structure of 2 is a single chain. The Ag(I) atom in complex 2 is coordinated by two nitrogen atoms of two IIMB ligands. Thus, the ratio of the metal to ligand is 1:1, while in complex 3 or 4, the metal ion [Cu(II) or Co(II)] is coordinated by four nitrogen atoms of four IIMB ligands, and the ratio of the metal to ligand is 1:2. As a result, the structures of 3 and 4 are double stranded chains. In complex 1, the ratio of metal to ligand is 1:4. Each Zn(II) ion is coordinated by four nitrogen atoms of four IIMB ligands. However, only the imidazole group connecting to the benzene ring through methylene group coordinates to the Zn(II) atom, and the one connected to the benzene ring directly remains free of coordination. Thus, 1 is a mononuclear compound instead of a double stranded chain. Furthermore, the relative ratio of the metal to ligand used during synthesis/crystallization of the complexes was found to not have great influence on the structure of the complexes.

elements.content: Complexes {[Cu(IIMB) 2 (SO 4 )]·8.5H 2 O} n (5) and {[Co(IIMB) 2 (H 2 O)(SO 4 )] 4 ·29H 2 O} n (6). When the reaction of ligand IIMB with copper(II) sulfate was carried out, complex 5 was obtained. As illustrated in Figure a, the asymmetric unit of complex 5 contains two copper(II) atoms, and each copper atom in complex 5 has a slightly distorted square-pyramidal environment and is coordinated by one oxygen atom of one sulfate ion and four nitrogen atoms of four IIMB ligands with the Cu−O band lengths of 2.371(8) and 2.271(9) and the Cu−N band lengths in the range of 1.876(13)−2.049(8) Å (Table S1). The Cu−O (SO4 2-) distance is shorter than that observed in complex [{Cu(4-DPDS)2(SO4)}·1.5H2O· CH3OH] n (where the 4-DPDS is 4,4‘-dipydyl disulfide and the Cu−O distance is 2.459(5) Å). The atom Cu1 lies 0.03 Å out from the N4 plane toward the O11 atom, while Cu2 lies 0.10 Å out from the N4 plane toward the O21 atom. Each IIMB ligand links two Cu1 (or two Cu2) atoms to form a double stranded chain containing 24-membered rings (Figure b). A similar double stranded chain is observed in [{Cu(4-DPDS)2(SO4)}·1.5H2O·CH3OH] n , and the sulfate in this complex not only takes part in coordination but also connects the double stranded chains into a 2-D sheet. However, in complex 5, the 1-D chains are interlaced with each other to generate a 2-D polycatenane network (Figure c, Figure S4). Similar structures are obtained by the reactions of ligand IIMB with cadmium(II) sulfate or manganese(II) sulfate.

elements.content: Complex 6 was obtained by the reaction of ligand IIMB with cobalt(II) sulfate. In complex 6, each Co(II) center with distorted octahedral geometry is coordinated by four imidazole groups of four IIMB ligands with the Co−N distances ranging from 2.102(9) to 2.158(8) Å and two O atoms from one water molecule and a sulfate anion with the Co−O distances ranging from 2.107(8) to 2.208(8) Å. The results of crystallographic analysis showed that the structures of 6 and 5 are similar (Figure S5), although the space group of 5 is C2, while the space group of 6 is P1̄.

elements.content: Although interpenetration is now common, the articles about 1-D chains interpenetrating to generate 2-D structures are rarely reported. Among these structures, the 1-D subunits are commonly of the ladder structure, and 2-D frameworks are obtained by the parallel interpenetration of 1-D structures (parallel refers not to the mean planes of the networks but to the direction of polymeric propagation). There are two exceptional examples of the 1-D → 2-D interpenetration reported.

Among these structures, the 1-D subunits are commonly of the ladder structure, and 2-D frameworks are obtained by the parallel interpenetration of 1-D structures (parallel refers not to the mean planes of the networks but to the direction of polymeric propagation). There are two exceptional examples of the 1-D → 2-D interpenetration reported.

elements.content: Here, we report exceptional examples of the 1-D → 2-D interpenetration and another two examples of 2-D entanglement generated by inclined interpenetration of 1-D chains as predicted by Ciani. The analysis of the complexes' structures with different anions informed that the key to the formation of 2-D polycatenane is the anion SO4 2-. That is to say, the nature of counteranions have a great influence on the structure topology of coordination polymers.

The analysis of the complexes' structures with different anions informed that the key to the formation of 2-D polycatenane is the anion SO4 2-. That is to say, the nature of counteranions have a great influence on the structure topology of coordination polymers.

elements.content: Photoluminescence Properties of the Complexes. The photoluminescence properties of complexes 1∼6 were studied in the solid state at room temperature. The measurements were carried out under the same experiment conditions. No clear photoluminescence was observed for 3−6 at room temperature. The luminescence emissions are probably quenched by the Cu(II) and Co(II) ions. As shown in Figure a, complexes 1 and 2 show luminescence with emission maxima at 468 ± 2 nm upon excitation at 397 nm, which is similar to that of ligand IIMB (emission maximum at 461 nm upon excitation at 397 nm, Figure S6). Complexes 1 and 2 exhibit photoluminescence with emission maxima around 437 ± 2 nm upon excitation at 366 nm (Figure b), which is quite similar to that of ligand IIMB (emission maximum at 437 nm upon excitation at 365 nm). The emissions observed in complexes 1 and 2 are tentatively assigned to the π−π* intraligand fluorescence due to their close resemblance of the emission bands.

cln_elements.content:
Synthesis of [Zn(IIMB) 4 (H 2 O) 2 ](NO 3 ) 2 ·5H 2 O (1). A solution of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (29.7 mg, 0.1 mmol) in water (20 mL) was added to a solution of IIMB (89.6 mg, 0.4 mmol) in H2O(10 mL). The mixture was stirred for ca. 30 min and then filtrated. Complex 1 was obtained by slow evaporation of the filtrate at room temperature in 48% yield. Anal. Calcd. for C52H62N18O13Zn:  C 51.51, H 5.15, N 20.79; found:  C 51.48, H 5.07, N 20.74.

Synthesis of {[Ag 2 (IIMB) 2 ][2,6-C 10 H 6 (COO) 2 ]·6H 2 O} n (2). A solution of IIMB (44.8 mg, 0.2 mmol) in methanol (7 mL) was layered over an aqueous solution of freshly prepared [Ag(NH3)2]2[2,6-C10H6(COO)2] (2,6-C10H6(COO)2 = 2,6-naphthalenedicarboxylate, 0.05 mmol mL-1, 4 mL). Colorless single crystals of 2 suitable for X-ray diffraction analysis were obtained by slow interlayer diffusion in 58% yield. Anal. Calcd. For C38H42Ag2N8O10:  C 46.27, H 4.29, N 11.36; found:  C 46.29, H 4.24, N 11.41.

Synthesis of {[Cu(IIMB) 2 Br 2 ]·0.5H 2 O} n (3). A solution of IIMB (44.8 mg, 0.2 mmol) in ethanol (7 mL) was layered over a solution of CuBr2 (22.3 mg, 0.1 mmol) in water (5 mL). Blue single crystals of 3 suitable for X-ray diffraction analysis were obtained by slow interlayer diffusion in 56% yield. Anal. Calcd. for C26H25Br2CuN8O0.50:  C 45.86, H 3.70, N 16.46; found:  C 45.94, H 3.68, N 16.39.

Synthesis of {[Co(IIMB) 2 (SCN) 2 ]} n (4). A solution of IIMB (44.8 mg, 0.2 mmol) in ethanol (7 mL) was layered over a solution of Co(SCN)2 (17.5 mg, 0.1 mmol) in water (5 mL). Pink single crystals of 4 suitable for X-ray diffraction analysis were obtained by slow interlayer diffusion in 56% yield. Anal. Calcd. for C28H24CoN10S2:  C 53.93, H 3.88, N 22.46; found:  C 54.02, H 4.03, N 22.28.

Synthesis of {[Cu(IIMB) 2 (SO 4 )]·8.5H 2 O} n (5). A solution of IIMB (67.2 mg, 0.3 mmol) in methanol (5 mL) and CuSO4·5H2O (37.5 mg, 0.15 mmol) in water (10 mL) was sealed in a stainless steel vessel and placed in an oven at 85 °C for 3 days. The bomb was cooled to room temperature, and then the solution was filtered. The complex 5 was obtained by slow evaporation of the filtrate at room temperature in 42% yield. Anal. Calcd. for C26H41CuN8O12.50S:  C 41.02, H 5.43, N 14.72; found:  C 41.21, H 5.38, N 14.80.

Synthesis of {[Co(IIMB) 2 (H 2 O)(SO 4 )] 4 ·29H 2 O} n (6). A solution of CoSO4·7H2O (28.1 mg, 0.1 mmol) in water (10 mL) was added to a solution of IIMB (44.8 mg, 0.2 mmol) in water (10 mL). The mixture was stirred for ca. 5 min and then filtrated. The complex 6 was obtained by slow evaporation of the filtrate at room temperature in 46% yield. Anal. Calcd. for C104H162Co4N32O49S4:  C 41.52, H 5.43, N 14.90; found:  C 41.50, H 5.63, N 14.92.

A solution of CoSO4⋅7H2O (28.1 mg, 0.1 mmol) in water (10 mL) was added to a solution of IIMB (44.8 mg, 0.2 mmol) in water (10 mL). The mixture was stirred for ca. 5 min and then filtrated. The complex 6 was obtained by slow evaporation of the filtrate at room temperature in 46% yield. Anal. Calcd. for C104H162Co4N32O49S4: C 41.52, H 5.43, N 14.90; found: C 41.50, H 5.63, N 14.92.

cln_elements.content: Photoluminescence Properties of the Complexes. The photoluminescence properties of complexes 1∼6 were studied in the solid state at room temperature. The measurements were carried out under the same experiment conditions. No clear photoluminescence was observed for 3−6 at room temperature. The luminescence emissions are probably quenched by the Cu(II) and Co(II) ions. As shown in Figure a, complexes 1 and 2 show luminescence with emission maxima at 468 ± 2 nm upon excitation at 397 nm, which is similar to that of ligand IIMB (emission maximum at 461 nm upon excitation at 397 nm, Figure S6). Complexes 1 and 2 exhibit photoluminescence with emission maxima around 437 ± 2 nm upon excitation at 366 nm (Figure b), which is quite similar to that of ligand IIMB (emission maximum at 437 nm upon excitation at 365 nm). The emissions observed in complexes 1 and 2 are tentatively assigned to the π−π* intraligand fluorescence due to their close resemblance of the emission bands.
